description: Borrowed from Latin decima (“a tenth”), now particularly via Italian decima. Doublet of decime.

entries.meaning: A tithe or tax of one-tenth (now usually in historical Italian contexts).
examples: He brandished his title as apostolic commissioner in court, and as supervisor of the papal decima in Tuscany.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, music) A tenth: a note nine degrees of the scale above or below a given note (and thus ten degrees separate counting inclusively) or the interval between such notes.
(music) An organ stop a tenth above the normal 8-foot pitch.

description: Borrowed from Spanish décima, from Latin decima (“a tenth”). Doublet of decime.

entries.meaning: (poetry) A 10-line verse or stanza, (chiefly) in the form of a song comprising an introductory verse followed by four such divisions.
examples: His album... dealt with the song form of Puerto Rican back-country troubadours, and it had a preoccupation with... the décima, a 10-line stanza with specific rhyme schemes.
